comments.commentBody: Perhaps sincere diplomacy may yet work.  In the 1970s Philippine rebels who wanted to secede three major islands from the Republic were supported by Khadaffi.  A high level diplomatic mission to Tripoli from the Philippines resulted in the ff. (1) an end to the hostilities in the rebel infested areas (2) the signing of the Tripoli Agreement creating two autonomous regions in southern Philippines in lieu of secession (3) the hiring of Filipino professional and skilled workers in Libya (4) preferential price of oil (5) and PEACE in southern Philippines.  Try talking oeace to Khadaffi.  He listens and a solution can be eventually arrived at.

I have a "one word diagnosis" - worms! This lady's immune system (which until now had been strong enough to keep them in check) was severely compromised by the extended care of her mother and then her death. This has allowed the parasites to multiply uncontrollably and their toxins to build up, causing many weird symptoms which can mimic a host of other diseases!

Unfortunately for her, modern "enlightened" Western medicine fails to recognize parasitic infestation in America, (although it's estimated that ca. 90% of the population suffers from this) and considers this a problem solely of third world countries.

A 30-day herbal-based general vermifuge would be my first line of defense and if her symptoms significantly improve or disappear, there's your diagnosis. Treatment may be repeated in 90 days, as necessary depending on the extent of the problem or if symptoms return.

"If you hear hoof beats, look for horses (first) then the zebras..."

Stage 3 Lyme disease, as others have said, is high on the differential. Geographically, the patient is in the right place. Lyme would also present with polyneuropathy and myriad cardiac insults (which would not show up in a cath lab). Most importantly, this is the stage in which severe encephalitis and neurocognitive defects can occur. The rash might be acrodermatitis chronic atrophricans, a late manifestation of Lyme disease, distinct from the more recognized erythema migrans.

I'd check the CSF for pleocytosis, and get titers right away.
Perhaps a drug addiction to one or more medications from her mother's medicine chest.  Narcotics?

I homeschool my two children in NY state. We use the JUMP math program because of my son's learning difficulties. Mighton and his team break down concepts into simple steps and lessons are not too long. My son has improved significantly in his understanding of mathematics. I like the program and will continue to use it. For 4th grade, it contains over 230 lessons divided into two workbooks, so it doesn't drop neatly into the 180-day American school year. However, we will continue to do a lesson per day throughout the summer to keep the kids sharp. You can find information about their program at http://www.jumpmath.org

Does anyone know if this is similar to FASTT Math (http://www.tomsnyder.com/fasttmath/index.html)? Does anyone know anything about FASTT Math? Our daughters' school is advocating this approach so I'd like to compare it with the JUMP Math progam.

It's a literacy issue.  Students who are not proficient in calculus and statistics are not fully literate people.  It is possible to have a very nice rewarding life being illiterate.  But it is harder to know what is really going on.

Although the description of the Jump method suggests that this way of teaching is a natural way to teach math, the idea of breaking down the steps in every subject is probably possible, while taking into consideration how other subjects differ from math.  The basic idea is that teachers should make sure that each step is understood before going on to the next step and that this builds the confidence that is necessary for young people to learn to love learning.  The most important requirement, then, is for teachers to learn the content they teach, understand how it is structured, and practice teaching by steps.  The example given for negative numbers, also incorporates practical experience, that is, using examples that illustrate, on the student's level, how to solve a problem, or understand a concept.  To a large extent, special education teachers (I was one), learn to do this with students who have difficulty learning.  As mentioned by others, some students seem to find it easier to gain insight without consciously using small steps, but probably actually do so if it was possible to see how their brains are really working!  Keep on writing about this and how these methods can be applied to all kinds of learning!

It is such a tragedy that those willing to endure such great personal danger to inform the rest of the world are no longer protected by the historically acknowledged protection of journalists. Tim and Chris were superlative photojournalists, acknowledged by their many awards. Condolences to their families, friends and colleagues. Thank you for supporting their many years of invaluable photojournalism. I hope that the profession, journalists, photojournalists, videographers, can endure the increasingly dangerous documentation of conflict for that is imperative for accountability in conflict throughout our world. A very sad day.

In general, prisons do not rehabilitate the inmates. The rehabilitating needs to happen _before_ children become murderers. And for God's sake (and the sake of everyone), it is essential that federal and state governments make the ownership--even the manufacture-- of guns and ammunition extremely limited. Yes, I'm going to put a political comment in my opinion here too: the GOP continues to de-fund important programs for children and youth (and their families) that help the younger generation to be prepared for, and aspire to, much loftier and legal goals than being criminals (drug dealers, prostitutes, thieves, and so on). And the GOP --but also the Democrats-- continue to bow to the power of the NRA and refuse to put very, very strong laws in place to prevent the manufacture and sales of weapons. On these policies do I put much of the blame for the creation and arming of young criminals such as the ones described in this article.
If you compare the violent, gun-loving U.S. with other countries (such as Canada) where sales and ownership of guns is extremely low (in particular when compared with the United States), you will see that gun violence is much less in those other countries. Hmm. We should think about that.
Furthermore, our schools and other institutions should provide excellent, appropriate, and affordable (or free) counseling to children and youth who show a propensity for crime and violence, and counsel the families and care-givers too.
Obviously we can't prevent every child from committing a crime--even a heinous crime--but we could sure do a lot better. The threat of being sentenced to jail certainly doesn't pose enough of a deterrent.

I took particular note of this phrase: "he is in the maximum-security prison here." Even if you accept that this person should still be in prison, why would he need to be in the max? Isn't that just a waste of money to make a silly point? Is this man actually perceived to be currently dangerous to society even while in prison?

The Supreme court is likely to go along with this not for reasons of justice but because of the cost of keeping people in prison who otherwise would most likely be homeless and sleeping under a palm tree in Florida.  Better for a bankrupt govenment to have high homeless and street people population than to continue racking up huge debts keeping people in prison and feeding and housing them at cost of about $50,000. a year per prisoner when you figure in guards salaries, etc.  Apparently the prison guard unions are the losers in any such new ruling along with possible safety of the general public.

14 year-olds aren't allowed to sit on juries.  The reason, no doubt, is that their powers of judgment are not mature, or that they wouldn't be able to understand the intricacies of a case.  So why not apply the same consideration to the competence of young offenders?

Hillary especially deserves to be dealt with sternly for her role which can only be explained by political ambition. This war might help BP or Total but that is not a valid reason for the U.S. to be involved and increasing the misery of the people in Libya.
